Dev meetings

DevMeetings for me Ring war nice by other developers for Developers. Simply the kind of what shop were one deweloper presents i to pick and other developers Are then challenged. Besides there’s one developer there are also other developers who act as mentors for participants. It happened that I was invited to be a mentor for the workshop on react native.

What They’ve learned

  • Expo

It’s very convienient tool to use especially on such occasion, when you have a couple of hours to present the most important stuff regarding a topic and you don’t want to waste it for configuration. It allows to setup from zero to running app on a device in minutes.

  • Props, state

The basics of React are all about these too. Props allow to compose components by sending from parents to children and state gives components ability to control encapsulated data.

  • Forms and AsyncStorage

Forms are bread nad butter of every frontend developer so it makes sense to present the idomatic way of writing them in React Native. This was the place where we used the power of state for the purpose of saving inputs on each keystroke and then push it to AsyncStorage on form submit.

AsyncStorage is not the perfect solution for this case, yet the API is pretty straight forward and gives a lot of functionalities without much boilerplate.

For web developers who want to try RN

Some React devs are a bit scared of starting using React Native and they ask questions whether it’s hard and what are the differences. 

React Native -> React

Well I can only say from my experience that moving from React Native to React was pretty seamless. Some stuff like hot reloading are based on web solutions, and they are not perfect though.

React -> React Native

So when I got back from React project to React Native project again It struck me how much more hassle to get it all working. Not to mention the deployment process.

The one difference that everybody notices at once is that in lieu of divs you are presented with View.

function React() (
  <div className={classes.container}>    Web devs comfort zone
  </div>
)
function ReactNative() (
  <View style={styles.container}>     Web devs feel apprehensive
  </View>
)

The other one is that there are no CSS as you know them from web. There are style properties instead, which you can then compose and you use camelCase to write them.

#ready {
  background-color: #123456;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
}
  
  #ready .container {
    padding: 0 10px; 
   }

Then in js:

function React() (
  <div id='ready'>
    <div className='container'/>
  </div>    
)

But in the React Native: 

const styles = StyleSheet.create({
  ready: {
    backgroundColor: '#123456',
    display: 'flex',
    justifyContent: 'center',
  },
  container: {
    padding: 0 10px; 
  },
});

function React() (
  <View style={styles.ready}>
    <View style={styles.container}/>
  </View>    
)

If writing properties in camel case is too exotic for you, let’s try with styled-components, which allows you to write them in your favourite way:

const Ready = styled.div` // or styled(View) in case of React Native
  background-color: '#123456';
  display: flex,
  justify-content: center,
`;

const Container = styled.div` // or styled(View) in case of React Native
  padding: 0 10px,
`;

function ReactOrReactNative() (
  <Ready>
    <Container/>
  </Ready>    
)

KOD

SessionStorage? LocalStorage? Well, both are part of Web Api, so they are not available in React Native :( but hey, you have access to something like AsyncStorage which in fact works similiarly to LocalStorage but has a set of additional convenience methods, and all of them return Promise.

KOD

Routing? So the most common lib for Navigation through an app, allows you to set up routing as you would do it on web. Set of screens that you access via navigation to an established route. Yet there is at least one difference, check if you can find it: 

KOD

Have you spotted it? No links in the routes, string based on the name of component instead. It’s simply because urls are not how you navigate through native apps. You can, however, use deep links to couple a url to the particular views. This functionality is used rather to navigate to the screen from outside the app, not to redirect to other screen when you are already in the app though.

What I’ve noticed

  • Whether you like it or not pair programming is simply an effective way of solving a couple of software development problems by:

  • boosting Distribution of knowledge. Diminish a number of bottlenecks in the organization by encourage other people to sit together and share their knowledge and work on solutions.

  • Alleviate communication bias. Real time meetings, especially when you see other people, are way more dynamic and allow you to express more with less words. Even though your wording might not be as specific as if you wrote them, you have ability of to express by gestures and intonation, which can convey emotions. Doubt, apprehension, excitment or cheer just to name a few.

  • Tights up a feedback loop. You don’t wait 2 days after you finished development to get a corrective feedback which then forces you to redesign the solution. And then you think that the worst thing here is that the new solution is simple better, if only you got it earlier…

How many things you can do when you are passionate and curious. Mr obvious strikes again, I know, but it hammered home to me during the last workshops. The task given to people are mostly far from being mundane and obvious to participants.

Also, there are many things I thought I’d known before I was asked to explain them in detail, like aforementioned difference between div and Text, or intricate details about Expo
